text:
SPEAKER 1: So, when
I was an activist,

I used to encourage
people not to pay

their bonds, their mortgages,
because we saw business

and the banking sector aiding
and abetting apartheid.

Toward the end of the '80s, into
the early '90s, began to see
business beginning to move.

And some of us
recognize that business

could be a motive force
for continuing change,
even into democracy.

Now, I was quite high up
on the Gauteng ANC list
for the first elections.

And at that time, myself
and Tokyo Sexwale,

who was chair of the
Gauteng ANC at that time,

and Paul Mashatile was
secretary general of the ANC

at that time, and
Tokyo Sexwale went on
to become premier of Gauteng.

Paul Mashatile is still on
the top leadership of the ANC.

And the three of us sat
down, and we had a discussion

and Tokyo said, look, all of
us can't go into government.

Some of us have got
to go into business
and start influencing business.

And that's a decision
was made that I do not

go into the Gauteng government
and was removed from the list.

And that was my start
into sort of business.

And I played a role
in the formation

of the first mutual
bank in this country

called Community Bank, which
was a low-income banking
initiative.

I then spent some time
with the Cohesio Group,
a small investment company.

And then I was approached by the
then CEO of the Banking Council

at that time, Bob
Tucker, who was

the CEO of one of
the biggest building

societies in the country before
then, to join the Banking
Association.

And when I joined the
Banking Association,

I began to see the critical role
that the banking sector could

play in developing this
economy and enabling people

to develop financial
assets and get access
to finance and so on.

And so provided
the industry began

to see that its role in the
socioeconomy, if you like,

is intricately linked to
its long-term sustainability
and profitability.

And that's how I've tried
to drive the Banking

Association and the industry
for the last 13-odd years.

And I think that
what's happened is

that the industry, if
you look at interaction

between government and
business, banking CEOs have

played a critical role
in that interaction.

I think the Banking
Association is

positioned as a credible
voice of the industry.

But government and
other stakeholders also

see the Banking
Association as a body,

and I remind my board about this
at the beginning of every year,

that I am not there to
make them feel comfortable.

I'm there to push the envelope,
to get them to do business

differently but still
profitably and sustainably,

but to do business in a way
that the banking sector is

relevant to as many people
in this country as possible.

And not like in the old days
where the banking sector

was relevant to only a
white minority essentially.

So that was the sort of
journey from an activist

that used to encourage
people not to pay mortgages

to actually representing the
banking sector in this country.
